prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

head.headtext: Disposition in the transferee court—Consent to trial in transferee district

para.paratext: In the post-Lexecon era, transferee courts have presided over trials of transferred cases under the authority of the parties' consent to trial by that judge.[1] These consents are sometimes referred to as “Lexecon waivers.”[2] It is not clear that this is proper, but it will be difficult for a losing party to appeal the question if consent was actually given. An appellate court could visit the question sua sponte, but a party would be hard-pressed to argue the issue unless it were deemed to be a matter of subject matter jurisdiction. A party agreeing to a Lexecon waiver should fully consider the matter, as courts require good cause to retract the waiver.[3]

Even without consent, the transferee can conduct trials of cases that were filed in the transferee court (as opposed to those transferred by the Panel). These trials may serve as bellwether trials.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re Farmers Insurance Exchange Claims Representatives' Overtime Pay Litigation, 336 F. Supp. 2d 1077 (D. Or. 2004).
See, e.g., In re Fosamax Products Liability Litigation, 2011 WL 1584584 (S.D.N.Y. 2011).

In re Bair Hugger Forced Air Warming Devices Products Liability Litigation, 322 F. Supp. 3d 911 (D. Minn. 2018); In re Fosamax Products Liability Litigation, 815 F. Supp. 2d 649, 653 (S.D. N.Y. 2011).

See generally Eldon E. Fallon, Jeremy T. Grabill & Robert Pitard Wynne, Bellwether Trials in Multidistrict Litigation, 82 Tul. L. Rev. 2323 (2008); Edward F. Sherman, The MDL Model for Resolving Complex Litigation if a Class Action is Not Possible, 82 Tul. L. Rev. 2205, 2213–16 (2008).
